key_points: George Floyd's heart disease and use of fentanyl were contributing factors to his death, not direct causatives, according to medical examiner Dr. Andrew Baker.
Dr. Baker classified Floyd's death as homicide, caused by cardiopulmonary arrest during law enforcement subdual, restraint, and neck compression.
Despite contributing factors, Dr. Baker emphasized the law enforcement actions as the primary cause of Floyd's death.
Defense suggested Floyd's death was due to drug use and preexisting health conditions, but Dr. Baker maintained his stance on homicide.
Forensic pathologist Dr. Lindsey Thomas testified that Floyd died from low oxygen, or asphyxia, due to law enforcement restraint.
Both medical professionals dismissed the idea that Floyd's health conditions and drug levels were relevant to his instantaneous death.
An independent autopsy commissioned by Floyd's family cited asphyxiation as the cause of death, contrasting the official autopsy that did not mention it.
Video evidence was crucial in concluding the cause and manner of Floyd's death, especially given the lack of anatomical evidence of asphyxiation.
Dr. Martin Tobin stated a healthy individual subjected to the same conditions would have also died.
Photos of Floyd's injuries were presented, supporting the conclusion that he was trying to position himself to breathe amidst restraint.
spokespersons: Dr. Andrew Baker (Hennepin County Chief Medical Examiner)
Dr. Martin Tobin (Pulmonary Critical Care Doctor)
